title-group.article-title: Gold and the Value-Growth Differential in Stock Returns

abstract.p: This study estimates the Fama-French-Carhart coefficients for gold returns for 1977 through 2009 and in subperiods of differing economic and monetary regimes. The results show that depending on the subperiod, the loading of gold on the SMB (small minus big) and UMD (up minus down) factors are either zero or significantly positive. The loading on the HMS (high minus low book-to-market equity ratio) factor switches between being significantly positive, insignificantly different from zero and significantly negative depending upon the subperiod. These results suggest that gold returns behave more like growth stocks in some periods and more like value stocks in other periods. Additional results show that adding gold to equity portfolios, irrespective of their style, improves their Sharpe ratios in most (but not all) economic regimes.
